name: ISO_11073_10101a_Ventilator_Codes
description: Used for mapping ventilation data attributes to ISO 11073 10101a codes from 2015

concept.definition: Specifies the absolute date and time for system or device clock and derived objects (resolution of up to 1/100 of a second, encoded as eight pairs of 4-bit BCD nibbles denoting the { century, year, month, day, hour, minute, second, sec-fractions }).
Specifies the relative time value for system or device clock and derived objects (default 125 ?s resolution counter having an arbitrary start time and value).
Absolute time stamp value for observations and derived objects.
Relative time stamp value for observations and derived objects.
Specifies the high-res relative time value for system or device clock and derived objects (default 1 ?s resolution counter having an arbitrary start time and value).
Hi-Res relative time stamp value for observations and derived objects.
This attribute defines the time handling capabilities and the status of the MDS. Usage of this attribute is required if synchronization or settable time is supported.

This attribute reports any date and time adjustments that occur either due to a person�s changing the clock or events such as daylight savings time. This is used in event reports only. If queried with Get MDS Object command, this value shall be not present or 0. If the agent ever adjusts the date and time, this attribute is used in an event report to report such adjustment.
Used in the Continua WAN interface to denote the certification authority body sub-element(s).
Specifies the timekeeping capabilities of the device(s) and system.  The MdsTimeCapState bit values are defined in IEEE Std 11073-20601:2014.
Specifies the time synchronization protocol (see Table A.11.4.2 for list of valid synchronization profiles).
Specifies the known or estimated accuracy of the device or system absolute or base-offset time relative to a reference time source such as NTP.
Specifies the resolution of the absolute date-time clock (if not the default value of 1/100 s).  For example, a clock that ticks at 1 s intervals would have a value of 100.
Specifies the resolution of the relative clock (if not the default value of 125 ?s).  For example, a clock that ticks at 1 s intervals would have a value of 8000.
Specifies the resolution of the high resolution relative clock (if not the default value of 1 ?s).  For example, a clock that ticks at 1 s intervals would have a value of 1000000.

Specifies the absolute date and time with local time-zone offset for system or device clock and derived objects expressed as a 64-bit value comprised of the 32-bit integer seconds, 16-bit fractional-seconds and signed 16-bit time-zone offset (in minutes).
Base-offset time stamp value for observations and derived objects.

Specifies the four octet NTP �Reference Identifier� that identifies the clock reference source.  This compact binary representation is dependent on the NTP version and NTP stratum of the clock reference source (IETF RFC 5905).
Specifes, as a text string, the universally unique identifier of the timebase providing the clock reference source.
Identifies the physiological measurement or technical source responsible for the alert
Specifies whether this message is the beginning, end or other state or state transition for the alert
Indicates the state of the underlying alert condition at the patient care device
Indicates whether visual or aural indications at the patient care device are inactivated
Alert priority
Alert type
Generic device, may be used as placeholder.
Generic device, of any type.
Generic device, of any type.
Instrument for the indirect measurement of respiration rate by estimating transthoracic impedance using the ECG leads.
Instrument for acquisition, analysis and detection of cardiac arrhythmias or conduction disturbances.
Instrument for acquisition, analysis and detection of haemodynamic pulse rate and other information.
Instrument for acquisition, analysis and detection of ST deviation and cardiac repolarization disturbances.
Instrument for the direct measurement of airway CO2 concentration and respiration rate.
Instrument for the non-invasive measurement of blood pressure.
Instrument for the measurement of the level of blood perfusion in cerebral tissue.
Instrument for the direct and continuous measurement of CO2 concentration or partial pressure.
Instrument for the indirect measurement of pCO2 partial pressure on the surface of the skin.
Instrument for the direct measurement of airway O2 concentration and respiration rate.
Instrument for the direct and continuous measurement of O2 concentration or partial pressure.
Instrument for the indirect measurement of pO2 partial pressure on the surface of the skin.
Instrument that measures temperature difference between two body sites or temperature reference.
Instrument that controls specific aspects of a device.
Instrument that processes or annunciates an alarm.
Instrument for the direct measurement of the pulmonary artery wedge pressure.
Instrument that derives the % of venous O2.
Device that stores physiologic information.
Instrument for measuring the rate of heart contractions.
Instrument for direct measurement and analysis of vital signs such as temperature, pulse or heart rate, blood pressure and respiratory rate.
Configurable (modular) instrument for direct measurement and analysis of vital signs.
Non-configurable (fixed functionality) instrument for direct measurement and analysis of vital signs.
Instrument displays alarm status.
Generic waveform device, of any type.
Generic numeric device, of any type.
Instrument or sensor for the direct measurement of pressure
Instrument for the measurement of blood perfusion.
Instrument for measuring changes in volume within an organ or body part due to fluctuations in the amount of blood or air it contains.
Instrument that derives cardiac parameters
Instrument that derives pulmonary parameters
Instrument that derives pulmonary parameters, where one or more inputs to the calculation may be clinically acceptable approximations or alternative values.
Instrument that derives the % of arterial O2 and pulse rate parameters (blood flow) and other analytes.
Instrument that derives the % of venous O2.
Instrument that measures gastric PgCO2 with tonometric catheters
Instrument that measures the EEG and derives a �bispectral index�, a computed EEG parameter.
Instrument that measures the EEG and derives an �entropy� index, a computed EEG parameter.
Instrument that measures the EEG and derives an �SNAP� index, a computed EEG parameter.
Instrument that measures the EEG and derives a �patient state index�, a computed EEG parameter.
Instrument that continuously derives heart output from direct measurement of blood flow.
Instrument that derives heart output from direct measurement of blood flow.
Instrument for modifying the ambient microenvironment for an infant, including skin temperature and ambient temperature, humidity and oxygen.
Instrument for modifying the ambient temperature for an infant.
Instrument for modifying the patient temperature for an infant.
Instrument for modifying the patient temperature using convective heating.
Instrument for modifying the patient temperature using radiant heating.
Instrument for the direct measurement of airway N2 concentration.
Instrument for the direct measurement of airway N2O concentration.
Device that aerosolizes medications, diluents and water in airway gas for inhalation by patient.
Instrument for the indirect measurement and estimation of cardiac and/or respiratory parameters by measuring the electrical conductivity of the thorax and its changes over time.
Heart rate obtained from the variation of transthoracic impedance.

Heart rate obtained from an artery that is close to the surface and a pulse can be felt.  [The most common places to measure heart rate using palpation are at the wrist (radial artery) and the neck (carotid artery).]
Work of left ventricle of the heart in one cardiac cycle and related to body surface area (LVSW/BSA)
The modality of fast-response SpO2 measurement. Rate of sampling of peripheral oxygen saturation by device.
The modality of slow-response SpO2 measurement. Rate of sampling of peripheral oxygen saturation by device.
The modality of spot-check SpO2 measurement.  Peripheral oxygen saturation.
Object containing sensor or pulse oximeter-specific status flags
Object containing status flags representing several characteristics of the pulse event
Initial acceleration of blood flow in the aorta, which occurs within the first 10 to 20 milliseconds
The ratio of the electrical and mechanical systole duration (PEP/LVET).
The electrical conductivity of the chest cavity, which is primarily determined by the intravascular, intraalveolar and the interstitial fluids in the thorax.
The time interval from opening to the closing of the aortic valve (mechanical systole).
The time interval from the beginning of electrical stimulation of the ventricles to the opening of the aortic valve (electrical systole).
Peak velocity of blood flow in the aorta.
Left-ventricular stroke volume per heart beat, normalized for body surface area.
Work performed by the left ventricle of the heart to eject the stroke volume over one minute's time, normalized for body surface area.
Work of right ventricle of the heart in one cardiac cycle and related to body surface area (RVSW/BSA)
Pressure of the blood in the femoral artery.
Systolic pressure of the blood in the femoral artery.
Mean pressure of the blood in the femoral artery.
Diastolic pressure of the blood in the femoral artery.
Flow of the blood in the pulmonary capillaries.
Oxygenation Ratio, calculated as the ratio of PaO2 (partial pressure of arterial oxygen) divided by FiO2 (the fractional of inspired oxygen, e.g. FiO2 in air = 0.21).
Quantity of blood pumped by the left ventricle into the aorta per minute, specifically by using the Fick method
Estimated O2 Consumption, normalized by body surface area
Estimated O2 Delivery, normalized by body surface area
Peripheral oxygen saturation level (of hemoglobin) to fraction of inspired oxygen ratio.  Equation:  100*SpO2(%)/FiO2(%).
Pressure of the blood in the femoral vein.
Pressure of the blood in the brachial artery.
Rate of breathing; method not specified
Rate of breathing; method: direct airway flow measurement.
Rate of breathing; method: transthoracic impedance variations
Rate of mechanical ventilation; method not specified
Rate of breathing; method: carbon dioxide measurement
Rate of breathing; method: non-airway pressure measurement, e.g. central venous blood pressure (CVP).

Rate of mechanical ventilation; method: carbon dioxide concentration measurement.  [This refers to the CO2 respiration rate measured by the ventilator and is not the set ventilator rate nor the ventilator inflation rate; it can include unassisted spontaneous breaths as well.]
Rate of mechanical ventilation; method: pressure measurement
Rate of mechanical ventilation, method: volume/flow relation (comment: pediatric)
Number of sighs delivered per minute during mechanical ventilation
Number of multiple sighs delivered per minute during mechanical ventilation
Rate of breathing; method: acoustic.
Rate of breathing; method: SpO2 plethysmography

concept.display: Spontaneous respiration rate (legacy devices and systems)
concept.definition: Spontaneous respiration rate, the rate of breaths initiated and terminated by the patient where pressure and flow/volume delivery are determined by the patient without support or assistance by a ventilator.  [This term may be used with legacy devices and systems where the precise definition of �spontaneous� is unknown; otherwise, the  more precise term MDC_RESP_BTSD_PS_RATE should be used.]

Spontaneous respiration rate, the rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow initiated by the patient where flow and/or volume is determined by the patient and are delivered with the intention that the breath will be terminated by the patient.
Difference in volume between maximum inspiration and maximum expiration
Duration of the expiratory phase from the end of expiratory flow to the start of inspiratory flow
Change of tidal volume per unit change of airway pressure
Change of tidal volume per unit change of transthoracic pressure
Change of tidal volume per unit change in esophageal pressure measured statically at expiration end

concept.display: Extrinsic PEEP (positive end expiratory pressure), applied
concept.definition: Positive end expiratory pressure applied to the airway.
.The component of alveolar pressure in the lungs above extrinsic PEEP due to physiologic causes at the end of expiration.
Pressure of gas in airway during expiration
Maximum pressure of gas in airway during expiration
Minimum airway pressure at any point during an expiratory phase before end expiration if less than end expiratory pressure
Pressure of gas in airway during inspiration

concept.definition: Maximum pressure of gas in airway during inspiration

Mean pressure of gas in airway during inspiration
Pressure measured in the esophagus
Pressure in intrapleural space during breathing
Ratio of carbon dioxide expired to oxygen used
Ratio of durations of inspiratory and expiratory phases
Ratio of dead space in respiratory tract to tidal volume
Resistance to gas flow within the airway
Resistance to gas flow in airway during expiration
Resistance to gas flow within the airway during inspiration
Duration of apnea due to airway obstruction
Duration of apnea - no flow measured
Duration of apnea - no flow and no respiratory effort
Duration of apnea with central and obstructive components
Volume of gas leaving the patient through the patient connection port during an expiratory phase.
Volume of gas in airway per breath not involved in respiratory�gas exchange�with no ventilator and no airway device.  It includes both alveolar and anatomical dead space.
Ventilated gas volume since start of inspiration (waveform)
Total volume of gas breathed in 1 min

Volume of gas per minute leaving the patient's airway during expiratory phases. [This term may be used with legacy devices and systems where the breath types are unknown; otherwise, the more precise term MDC_VOL_MINUTE_AWAY_EXP_BTSD_PSAZC should be used.]
Volume of gas per minute entering the patient's airway during inspiratory phases
Concentration of carbon dioxide in airway gas during mechanical ventilation
Concentration of carbon dioxide in airway gas measured at the end of expiration during mechanical ventilation
Concentration of carbon dioxide in airway gas measured in expiration during mechanical ventilation
Concentration of carbon dioxide in airway gas measured in inspiration during mechanical ventilation

concept.definition: Measured partial pressure of oxygen in airway gas

The negative airway pressure generated when briefly occluded during inspiration

Minimum assured ventilation rate in modes that support spontaneous breaths
Total rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow comprised of unassisted�(P), supported�(S), assisted�(A), synchronized assisted (Z) and controlled�(C) breath types.

concept.display: Unassisted spontaneous breath rate; respiration rate
concept.definition: Rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow initiated and terminated by the patient where pressure and flow/volume delivery are determined by the
Rate of inflations or inspiratory gas flow initiated by the patient and that are intended to be terminated by the patient where the inspiratory pressure is raised above baseline to
Rate of primary inflations initiated by the patient at greater than the set rate.  The associated breaths are classified as having been

Rate of primary inflations that have been assured to be delivered at the average set rate but are initiated by the patient within a timed synchronization window. The associated breaths are classified as having had
Rate of primary inflations that are initiated by the ventilator at the set rate.  These breaths are classified as being

Rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow initiated by the patient where flow and/or volume is determined by the patient and is delivered with the intention that the breath will be terminated by the patient.  Includes unassisted and supported breaths that are superimposed on the intermittently elevated baseline pressure with APRV, bilevel or spontaneous-only modes.
Rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow that are delivered as assisted, synchronized assisted or controlled breaths by the ventilator, at an average or�minimum rate set by the ventilator.
Rate of breaths or inspiratory gas flow initiated by the patient that are unassisted or delivered as supported, assisted or synchronized assisted breaths.
The ventilator calculated target respiratory rate, typically used to achieve a desired minute volume or other objective.
Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF): maximum flow measured at the mouth during an expiration delivered with maximal

This value is determined by a healthcare professional or based on predicted average peak flow and is typically the highest peak condition.expiratory flow (PEF) reading an individual can obtain while in peak
It is a measure of expiratory volume of a subject under forced conditions at 1 s, measured from time zero (time at which subject starts the expiration).
It is a measure of expiratory volume of a subject under forced conditions at 6 s, measured from time zero (time at which subject starts the expiration).

Resistance to gas flow within the airway, dynamically calculated using a least squares or other curve fitting algorithm where airway resistance and lung compliance are related by the �equation of motion� ?P

Change of tidal volume per unit change of airway pressure, dynamically calculated using a least squares or other curve fitting algorithm where airway resistance and lung compliance are related by the �equation of motion� ?P
Duration of the inflation phase if time-terminated, expressed as a percent-ratio of the total respiratory period
Duration of an inspiratory phase
Duration of an expiratory phase
The duration of the inspiratory phase for controlled (primary) inflations when a backup inflation is delivered.
The maximum inspiratory time for a pressure-supported breath.
Interval from the end of inspiratory flow to the start of expiratory flow during unassisted spontaneous breathing and pressure-regulated inflations, expressed as a time duration.

Interval from the end of inspiratory flow to the start of expiratory flow during unassisted spontaneous breathing and pressure-regulated inflations, expressed as a percentage of the duration of the inspiratory phase.

The duration of an inspiratory hold, a ventilator function intended to temporarily maintain a constant lung volume, or to maintain a constant airway pressure, at the end of an inspiratory or inflation phase.
Duration for an expiratory hold, a ventilator function intended to temporarily maintain a constant lung volume during a set extension of the expiratory phase.
Inspiratory time divided by the total respiratory cycle time, expressed as a percent.
The time duration that the ventilator holds the high  (inspiratory) baseline pressure level in APRV or Bi-Level modes.
The time duration that the ventilator holds the low (expiratory) baseline pressure level in APRV or Bi-Level modes.

The continuous flow that is circulated through the patient circuit but is not intended to contribute to the work of ventilation. Generally refers to a low-level flow that improves the responsiveness and accuracy of the ventilator�s control and detection systems and to minimize rebreathing of expired gas.

A continuous flow that passes through the ventilator breathing system, with a proportion intermittently passing to the patient�s lung (e.g. whenever the airway pressure is raised by a pressure-controlled occlusion of the expiratory valve).
Volume of inspired gas during each breath, breath type(s) not specified.

Volume of expired gas for each breath, breath type(s) not specified. [This term may be used with legacy devices and systems where the breath types are unknown; otherwise, the more precise term MDC_VOL_AWAY_TIDAL_EXP_BTSD_PSAZC should be used.]

concept.display: Expired Tidal Volume per body mass
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas for all breath and inflation types, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg), reported individually or as an average.
Volume of expired gas for all breath and inflation types, reported individually or as an average.

concept.display: Expired Tidal Volume for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths.

concept.display: Expired Tidal Volume for assisted, synchronized assisted or controlled (aka mandatory) breaths
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas for assisted, synchronized assisted or controlled (aka mandatory) breaths.

concept.display: Expired Tidal Volume for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths per body mass
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg).

concept.display: Expired minute volume per body mass
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas per minute leaving the patient's airway, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg), all breath and inflation types.

concept.display: Expired minute volume (total for all breath types)
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas per minute for all breath and inflation types (total).

concept.display: Expired Minute volume for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas per minute for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths.

concept.display: Expired Minute volume for assisted or controlled (aka mandatory) inflations
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas per minute for assisted, synchronized assisted or controlled (aka mandatory) breaths.

concept.display: Expired Minute volume for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths per body mass
concept.definition: Volume of expired gas per minute for unassisted or supported (aka spontaneous) breaths, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg).
Integral flow of gas in airway, typically as a waveform or spirometry waveform segment
Pressure of gas in airway measured at the end of the inspiratory phase (this may be coincident with the peak inspiratory pressure or the plateau pressure and thus may have the same value as either).
Baseline airway pressure

concept.display: Inspiratory airway pressure relative to PEEP or BAP
concept.definition: Inspiratory airway pressure relative to PEEP or BAP.
The inspiratory airway pressure for controlled (primary) inflations when a backup inflation is delivered.

concept.display: Backup inspiratory airway pressure relative to PEEP or BAP
concept.definition: The inspiratory airway pressure relative to PEEP or BAP for controlled (primary) inflations when a backup inflation is delivered.
The inspiratory airway pressure for pressure support inflations.
The inspiratory airway pressure relative to PEEP or BAP for pressure support inflations.
The high (inspiratory) pressure level for APRV or Bi-Level modes.
The low (expiratory) pressure level for APRV or Bi-Level modes.
The pressure at which the breath is limited and held for the remaining inspiratory time in a volume-controlled breath.
The maximum pressure allowed in the patient breathing circuit. Once reached, the inspiratory phase ends, and the ventilator immediately begins the expiratory phase.
Threshold value at which a protection device prevents any further rise in the airway pressure
The minimum target pressure limit.
The minimum target pressure limit relative to PEEP or BAP.
The time for pressure to reach a preset fraction of the set inspiratory pressure for controlled inflations.
The time for pressure to reach a preset fraction of the set inspiratory pressure for support breaths.
The estimated airway pressure that would have occurred during an inspiratory-hold or during a flow pause in a pressure control inflation.
The negative airway pressure generated during the first 100 ms of an occluded inspiration
The maximum negative airway pressure generated during an occluded inspiration arising from a Negative Inspiratory Force (NIF) maneuver
The sum of the extrinsic PEEPe and intrinsic PEEPi, representing the total pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration.
Dynamic extrinsic PEEP, the minimum pressure at or near the end of expiration, reflecting the set PEEP from the ventilator.
Dynamic intrinsic PEEP, obtained during the short period between expiratory valve closure and flow arriving at the patient.
Dynamic total PEEP, obtained during the short period between expiratory valve closure and flow arriving at the patient.
Sensitivity of trigger in ventilator; a flow value, for triggering an inflation.
Flow threshold in ventilator to end the inspiratory phase, expressed as a flow value.
Expended energy measurement (or estimate) using indirect calorimetry based on O2 consumption and CO2 production by patient, measured over a period of time.

concept.display: O2 Consumption per body mass (typ kg)
concept.definition: The volume of oxygen a patient inhales (consumes) per minute, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg).

concept.display: O2 Consumption per body surface area (typ m
concept.definition: The volume of oxygen a patient inhales (consumes) per minute, normalized by patient body surface area (typ m

concept.display: CO2 Production per body mass (typ kg)
concept.definition: Rate of production of carbon dioxide, measured by expired carbon dioxide in airway per unit time (typ  /min), normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg).

concept.display: CO2 Production per body surface area (typ m
concept.definition: Rate of production of carbon dioxide, measured by expired carbon dioxide in airway per unit time (typ  /min), normalized by patient body surface area (typ m
Barometric (atmospheric) air pressure
Ambient (immediate patient environment) air pressure
The (estimated) fraction of cardiac output that returns to the left heart without the benefit of exposure to ventilated alveoli.
The (estimated) difference in the oxygen content of the blood between the arterial blood and the venous blood.
Partial pressure of CO2 in the pulmonary artery
Pulmonary Vascular Resistance Index, normalized with respect to body surface area
The (estimated) ratio (fraction) of oxygen that is consumed divided by the oxygen that is delivered.
The rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) is calculated by dividing the spontaneous breath rate by the tidal volume, averaged over one minute.
Sum of the Minimum Alveolar Concentration for anesthetic gas and N2O
Age corrected sum of the Minimum Alveolar Concentration for anesthetic gas and N2O
Mean Aveolar Concentration, expressed as a percentage relative to the needed to prevent movement (motor response) in 50% of subjects in response to surgical (pain) stimulus.
Flow of Air component of Fresh Gas
Volume (gas) of air delivered during a case, to a single patient during a single procedure.
Total volume (gas) of air delivered (potentially across multiple cases)
Air supply (pipeline) pressure
Air cylinder pressure

Total volume of xenon gas delivered (potentially across multiple cases)
Volume of gas leaving the patient through the patient connection port, normalized by the patient�s ideal body weight (typ kg), reported individually or as an average for all breath types.
The ventilator calculated target volume of gas delivered to the patient.
The volume of gas delivered to the patient when a backup inflation is delivered.
Volume of inspired gas during ventilator inflations.

Relative volume of gas lost per minute by leakage in ventilation system, tubing, connectors, etc. calculated as the difference between inspired and expired volume, relative to inspired volume, expressed as a percentage.

concept.display: Reference minute volume calculated for the patient�s ideal body mass
concept.definition: The reference minute volume calculated for the patient, based on the patient�s ideal body weight
The calculated target minute volume, the product of reference minute volume and the percentage set by the clinician.
Volume of gas exchanged per minute in alveoli; difference between tidal volume and dead space
Pressure measured in the stomach
The measured or estimated difference between the alveolar pressure and the intrapleural pressure.
The pressure of the balloon that seals the endotracheal tube.

concept.display: Endotracheal cuff pressure at the end of exhalation
concept.definition: The pressure of the balloon that seals the endotracheal tube at the end of exhalation.
The time for pressure to reach a preset fraction of the set inspiratory pressure for controlled inflations, expressed as a percentage of the duration of the inspiratory phase.
The time for pressure to reach a preset fraction of the set inspiratory pressure for support breaths, expressed as a percentage of the duration of the inspiratory phase
Flow threshold in ventilator to end the inspiratory phase, expressed as a percentage of peak inspiratory flow.

The work expended by the patient over one or more inspiratory and expiratory cycles.  Includes the physiologic resistive and elastic components of work and may exclude the work done by stored potential energy of the lung compliance overcoming airway resistance and tissue movement resistance during expiration.  The preferred calculation method is based on the Campbell diagram in which lung volume on the ordinate is plotted against the pleural or esophageal pressure on the abscissa and does not include the additional work WOBi imposed on the patient by the breathing apparatus.  Can be expressed as work per breath, work per unit volume, work per unit time (power) or work per unit volume per body mass.[1]
The resistive component of the work of breathing by the patient, using principles based on the Campbell diagram.
The elastic component of the work of breathing by the patient, using principles based on Campbell diagram.

The work of breathing expended by the ventilator and applied to the patient over one or more inspiratory/inflation and expiratory cycles, calculated or estimated relative to the patient airway adaptor, endotracheal tube, endotracheal tube tip near the carina or other measurement site.[2]
The additional resistive work imposed on the patient by the breathing apparatus (endotracheal tube, breathing circuit, humidifier, demand valves and exhalation valves)

The integral of the transdiaphragmatic pressure (Peso � Pga) over the time interval between the start of the inspiratory effort and the end of the inspiratory phase of a respiratory cycle.  Reflects the exertion of the respiratory muscles during inspiration.  PTP can be expressed per breath or per unit time for multiple breaths.

Endotracheal or tracheal tube compensation level, expressed as a percent from 0 (off) to 100 (full compensation) relative to level estimated by the ventilator based on tube type and size.  Compensation method not specified.
Tube type, endotracheal or tracheal.
Tube size (inside diameter) in millimeters.
The product of the inspiratory airway resistance and static compliance.
The time needed for the lungs to passively deflate by a certain amount or a percentage of volume.

concept.display: Slope of the alveolar plateau CO2 concentration with respect to expired volume
concept.definition: The slope of the CO2 concentration with respect to the expired gas volume during the alveolar plateau (Phase III) representing the emptying of alveoli with CO2-rich gas.  Method:  volumetric capnography.
Volume of expired CO2 during each breath, breath type(s) not specified.
Volume of inspired CO2 during each breath, breath type(s) not specified.
Volume of expired O2 during each breath, breath type(s) not specified.
Volume of inspired O2 during each breath, breath type(s) not specified.
Number of cycles remaining, including the current cycle.  Transitions to zero when delivery completed.

concept.display: Remaining nebulization time for current cycle
concept.definition: Remaining nebulization time for current cycle.  Transitions to zero at the start of the pause interval when delivery for the current cycle is completed

concept.display: Total remaining nebulization time for current set of delivery cycles
concept.definition: Total remaining nebulization delivery time for current set of delivery cycles (does not include pause time).

concept.display: Elapsed nebulization time for current cycle
concept.definition: Elapsed time that fluid has been nebulized for current cycle.

concept.display: Total elapsed nebulization time for current set of delivery cycles
concept.definition: Total elapsed time that fluid that has been nebulized for current set of delivery cycles.

concept.display: Remaining fluid to be nebulized for current cycle
concept.definition: Estimated remaining volume of fluid to be nebulized for current cycle.

concept.display: Total remaining fluid to be nebulized for current set of delivery cycles
concept.definition: Estimated total remaining volume of fluid to be nebulized for current set of delivery cycles.

concept.display: Volume of fluid that has been nebulized for current cycle
concept.definition: Estimated volume of fluid that has been nebulized for current cycle.

concept.display: Total volume of fluid that has been nebulized for current set of delivery cycles
concept.definition: Estimated volume of fluid that has been nebulized for current set of delivery cycles.

Additional inspiratory gas flow due to pneumatic nebulizer, externally indicated by a wall flow meter or other sensor.  This information can be manually or automatically entered and typically requires compensation by the ventilator.
EEG Signal Quality Index, an indication of overall signal quality for calculating processed EEG variables such as BIS and interpreting EEG results.
Electromyographic signal strength, predominantly representing muscle activity above 70 Hz.

The bispectral index (BIS) is a quantitative assessment of depth of anesthesia, specifically the level of consciousness.  It is an index that ranges from 0 to 100.  No�measurable cortical activity would result in a BIS of 0 and a typical awake state is usually associated with an index of 90 to 100. Typical values for a patient undergoing general anesthesia are 40 to 60.

A computed EEG variable used for assessing the depth of anesthesia based on the irregularity of the FEMG signal in the 0.8 to 47 Hz frequency band. Typical values for patients undergoing general anesthesia are between 40 and 60, and at these levels of entropy response, the probability of patient accidental awareness is low.  The overall display range for RE is 0 to 100.

A computed EEG variable used for assessing the depth of anesthesia based on the irregularity of the EEG signal in the 0.8 to 32 Hz frequency band.  Typical values for patients undergoing general anesthesia are between 40 and 60, and at these levels of entropy state, the probability of patient accidental awareness is low.  The overall display range of SE is 0 to 91.

A computed EEG variable used to help assess the level of consciousness while under anesthesia based on the high- and low-frequency EEG.  Index values range from 0 to 100, with 0 reflecting no measurable cortical activity and 100 reflecting the awake state.
A computed EEG index used to help assess the depth of sedation and anesthesia based on a multivariate combination of EEG variables.
Epileptic or potentially epileptogenic activity identifiers, spike count
Epileptic or potentially epileptogenic activity identifiers, burst count
Epileptic or potentially epileptogenic activity identifiers, burst rate
Whole blood glucose concentration taken from capillary
Plasma glucose concentration taken from capillary
Whole blood glucose concentration taken from venous
Plasma glucose concentration taken from venous
Whole blood glucose concentration taken from arterial
Plasma glucose concentration taken from arterial
Glucose concentration measurement produced from control solution
Glucose concentration measurement indirectly derived from interstitial fluid
Base excess of extracellular fluid
A1c or glycated hemoglobin concentration.
Base excess of arterial blood
Ionized calcium in blood fluid, normalized to pH 7.4
The globally recommended normalized unit for measuring prothrombin time
The time taken for a clot to form on the addition of a thromboplastin to a sample of venous or capillary blood
The measured prothrombin time is expressed in relation to the coagulation time of a healthy person, i.e., the �percentage of the standard value.�
Standardized calibration for a thromboplastin compared to the WHO standard.
Control Solution of INR monitor
An estimate of the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin plus the amount of oxygen dissolved in arterial blood (not bound to hemoglobin).
Carboxyhemoglobin concentration in the arterial blood, measured by pulse oximetry.
Methemoglobin concentration in the arterial blood, measured by pulse oximetry.
Total Hemoglobin concentration in the arterial blood, measured by pulse oximetry.
Preductal oxygen saturation measured at a site that receives blood flow from the aorta before the level of the ductus arteriosus (see�Note 1).
Postductal oxygen saturation is measured at a site that receives blood flow from the aorta after the level of the ductus arteriosus (see�Note 2).
The difference between preductal and postductal oxygen saturation measurement (see Note 3).
Difference (gap) between gastric mucosal (PgCO2) and arterial (PaCO2) partial pressures of carbon dioxide.
Difference (gap) between gastric mucosal (PgCO2) and end-tidal (EtCO2) partial pressures of carbon dioxide.
Gastric mucosal (PgCO2) partial pressure of carbon dioxide.
Intramucosal pH
SpO2 Signal Quality Index, an indication of overall signal quality for calculating SpO2 and other values using pulse oximetry.
Whole blood glucose concentration taken from undetermined sample source
Plasma glucose concentration taken from undetermined sample source
The oxygen concentration inside the incubator micro-environment.
Measured relative humidity inside the infant incubator
Compartment probe (incubator air) temperature
The heater power is the percentage of power (or actual power in watts) necessary to maintain the set temperature of the incubator or warmer.

concept.display: Incubator heater heat sink temperature sensor resistance
concept.definition: Incubator heater heat sink and fin assembly temperature sensor resistance
Incubator heater heat sink and fin assembly temperature
An enumeration that indicates the maximal inrush of the pulsatile wave has occurred

The type of bed used for an infant in the neonatal intensive care unit or newborn nursery. A radiant warmer is an open bed, an incubator is a closed bed, and an incubator that can serve as a radiant warmer is a combination bed.
Incubator or warmer heater currently being used.  This may include radiant, convective or none (no heat).
The bed state indicates whether the infant�s incubator is closed, partially open or open, i.e. the top of the incubator is raised.

The air curtain on an incubator is a specially-designed airflow to reduce temperature fluctuation and maintain the temperature inside the incubator when its access doors are opened.  The air curtain state indicates whether the air curtain is on, off or has been disabled by the user.

Specifies the manner in which the temperature of an infant incubator or radiant warmer is controlled.  For�closed beds (incubators) the temperature is controlled based on patient sensor or air temperature.  For�open beds (open incubator or warmer) the temperature is controlled based on patient sensor or manually set temperature.
The speed of the fan that controls the airflow in an infant incubator, such as low or high.
Selected mode of ventilator
Selected mode of respirator
Selected backup mode of ventilator
The identity of volatile anesthetic agents that have been detected and/or are known to be present in airway gas during inspiration and/or inflation.
The identity of the balance (carrier) gases that have been detected and/or are known to be present in airway gas during inspiration and/or inflation.
Specifies the nebulizer type, such as an aerosolizer (using a micro pump) or pneumatic (using an external air or oxygen supply).
Specifies the nebulizer operational status, such as nebulizer on/off, nebulizer failure, no nebulizer, nebulizer not connected and other information.
Axillary (armpit) temperature
Gastro-intestinal tract temperature
Transcutaneous sensor heater power
Transcutaneous sensor temperature
Axillary (armpit) temperature
Myocardial temperature
Nasal temperature
Room temperature
The measurement of the mass of patient, e.g., by a scale in bed, e.g., during therapy
The individual's body fat in kilograms divided by the individual's weight in kilograms
The individual's body weight, in kilograms, divided by the square of height, in meters
The sum of the soft lean mass and mineral mass in the human body.
The sum of the soft lean mass in the human body.
The individual's body water in kilograms divided by the individual's weight
Last Taken Weight
Ideal body weight (IBW), an estimate based solely on patient height using the Devine Formula (1974):
Adjusted Body Weight, an estimate based on the IBW and following rule:

Right ear (theta 120, phi 0)

Synchronized via Health Level 7 NCK (network clock)
CDMA mobile telecommunications synchronization
GSM - Network Identity and Time Zone (NITZ)
A manually set time, by �eyeball and wristwatch�
Synced to the 1kHz USB "start-of-frame" clock
A time sync method that is out of scope for IEEE 11073
A time sync method based on other mobile network technology that is not listed above
A time sync method based on GPS information
Regulation-Certification-Continua-Version (hypothetical decomposition of MDC_ATTR_REG-CERT-DATALIST Continua Body Certified Device Version sub element)
Regulation-Certification-Continua-Certified-Device-List (hypothetical decomposition of MDC_ATTR_REGCERT-DATA-LIST Continua Body Certified Device List sub element)
Regulation-Certification-Continua-Regulation-Status (hypothetical decomposition of MDC_ATTR_REGCERT-DATA-LIST Continua Body Regulation Status sub element)
Regulation-Certification-Continua-AHD-Cert-List
Displayed minimum and/or actual ventilator rate setting, may be mode dependent.

concept.display: Minimum assured ventilation inflation rate setting
concept.definition: Minimum assured ventilator-initiated inflation rate, e.g. in continuous mandatory ventilation or assist/mandatory ventilation mode.
Average ventilator-initiated inflation rate, e.g. in Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation (SIMV) ventilation mode.
Positive end expiratory pressure applied to the airway during spontaneous breathing, e.g. by an expiratory valve on the breathing circuit.
Inspiratory airway pressure setting.
Positive end expiratory pressure applied to the airway by the ventilator during expiratory phase.
The maximum inspiratory time to deliver a pressure-controlled or operator-set tidal volume inflation.
Apnea (backup) rate, e.g. in CSV mode.
Interval from the end of inspiratory flow to the start of expiratory flow during volume-control (VC) inflations, expressed as a time duration.
Interval from the end of inspiratory flow to the start of expiratory flow during volume-control (VC) inflations, expressed as a percentage of the duration of the inspiratory phase.
Minimum volume of inspired gas during ventilator inflations.

concept.display: Percentage of the reference minute volume calculated for the patient�s ideal body mass
concept.definition: The percentage of the reference minute volume (calculated for the patient based on the patient�s ideal body weight) set by the clinician.
Specifies the nebulizer run time per delivery cycle.
Specifies the nebulizer volume per delivery cycle.
Specifies the number of nebulizer delivery cycles having a specified run time and/or volume when operating in scheduled mode.
Specifies the pause (time duration) between nebulizer delivery cycles when operating in scheduled mode.
The identity of volatile anesthetic agents based on user selection of vaporizer and/or cassette.
The identity of the balance (carrier) gases based on user selection.

Specifies the nebulizer operational mode, including intermittent, scheduled or continuous modes.  Selecting intermittent mode delivers a single timed delivery based on the programmed run time and/or volume, and for scheduled mode, the number of cycles and pause time between cycles.  Selecting continuous mode delivers nebulized medication until the medication runs out or delivery is stopped.
